etymologies: early 20th century; earliest use found in Proceedings of the American Philosophical Society. From re- + migrant, originally after scientific Latin remigrantes, plural

definitions: In aphids and other plant lice: a female of a winged parthenogenetic generation (sexuparae) that returns to the primary plant host in the autumn.
In vertebrates, especially sea turtles: an individual that migrates back to a site where it has bred in previous seasons.
